I regret not being a better friend to a woman about 15 years ago. I eventually found out she had a recurring cancer but at the time I didn't know the depth of her illness. She was bright, intelligent, and engaging, funny and so sweet. An accomplished author and instructor, we met at an authors event - I purchased her book, we chatted and she signed it for me. We stayed in touch, occasionally meeting for coffee, happy hour etc. She could even dance (ballroom) and delighted finding that I could as well. Once, at a Starbucks, we danced a impromptu two-step on the patio. We laughed and had fun.
She asked me several times to do other things with her but for various reasons (work, etc) I declined. I realize now these were important to her, activities that would have brought her joy that I could have easily done. Her illness returned and we had planned to walk an art fair together but she was too sick. I saw her once at the hospital and she died from cancer shortly after. I loved her so much.
I regret not spending more quality time with my parents when they were at the end of their life and not being beside them at the moment when they passed away.

At the age of 41, I had an affair with another woman while still married to my husband of almost 20 years.  I subsequently divorced my husband and left my 10 year old son in the custody of his father.   Although I was very unhappy in my marriage, my regret is the pain and hurt I inflicted on my son.  I regret not finding a less damaging way to leave my husband.  My actions were morally bankrupt and caused irreparable damage to my son, my husband and myself.
married the wrong man. could not figure a way out of that marriage
I was closeted as a teen and had a couple sexual experiences with a best friend who I loved romantically.  I regret never telling him that I loved him.

Believing the assurances of the Nursing Home director, nurse, and other staff that they would take care of my dear mother better than I could at home in March 2020 when the Covid-19 lockdown began, they convinced me to leave her in their care. A month later, she was dead because of their neglect and not from Covid!  I was two miles away, outside her closed window daily, but couldn’t talk to her. She was OK, they always insisted. One afternoon I saw she was unresponsive, had her sent to the ER, but was already septic from a Level 4 Decubitus Ulcer to the bone and Aspiration Pneumonia, neither condition she’d had beforehand. Despite heroic efforts by the hospital, she died five nights later. This is my biggest regret, and one I can barely live with.  Mother never failed me once in my whole life, loved me more than anyone in the world and I her, and she died on my watch. I was her POA, entrusted with her care, and she’s gone forever because of their greed. Life is meaningless now.
using alcohol to the point of losing control

I regret not being a gracious person when my cousin and his wife asked me if they could stay at our home while they attended a reunion.  That event ended a close, friendly relationship with them. We still are cordial at family gatherings but we are no longer the close friends we once were.
I most regret being unable to accept the interest and kindness that some mentors showed me.

I regret not marrying a good man who wanted to have a family with me, I was 22 years old. I thought he was not good enough for me. Few years later , I met another man that I loved so much, and i think he did too, we spent almost 8 years together, however love lasted only 3 or 4 years, he said he wanted a life with me, he promised and i believed. I regret i believed in his promises. We passed through a lot, good and bad times together,  time passed and he showed that he wanted to be single. He decided he didnt want to continue with our relationship and after a year he got married. We stopped any contact for almost 4 or 5 years, i got married, he got divorced. I had always thought about him and our life full of dreams. We reconmected but I was married. He found a new partner, he has a child with her and about a week ago he sent me a message about our past and the good memories together. I now regret the fact that we didn't fight for our love. Its too late.

In my mid 20's I regret choosing the wrong graduate school which ended up being a total waste of two years and money. I stupidly went for the Ivy League school with a better "brand" when the other highly reputable school had a much better program that would have prepared me for a fulfilling career. I ended up stuck and unhappy the neighborhood after graduate school with a series of mostly dead-end jobs that have plagued my entire career.  The message is don't pick a school based on its brand, go for the better program more closely aligned with your goals and dreams.

My biggest regret is not working part-time instead of full time while raising my children. As a mother I felt chronically stressed by the demands of work, family and home.  Although I am proud to say that my children, now young adults, are doing well, both have struggled with depression and anxiety.

I regret not moving in with my mom and her husband, who had dementia, so she wouldn’t have to sell their house. Now she is in Assisted Living, he has passed, and she really misses her home. I could have helped. The end of her life would be much happier.

I regret not moving away from my family immediately after college. I allowed myself to be convinced to stay to help take care of my brother's two sons because he and their mothers were not up to the task. I lost most of my 20s to caretaking when I could have been traveling and completing my graduate degree. I have since been quite staunch in not allowing my pursuits to be sidetracked by others but the lost time is something I will never regain.

I regret not doing more to help my mother after she got a cancer diagnosis.  My brother was there to help, but he already had others he needed to help.  Both would have benefitted if I was there.  This was a turning point in their health.  My mother did beat the cancer, but her health continued to decline as did my brother's health.  I was my mother's primary caregiver in the last two years of her life, which also took the load off my brother.  However,  the damage had already been done.  Both might have had a better quality of life and lived longer had I helped sooner.

Of all of my regrets one still brings me to my knees. Our beloved Jed died alone in a crate at the emergency Vet with a muzzle on when we should have had him euthanized. It's not about the money we spent trying to save him but the ignorance of everyone involved. The quality of life should have been measured by my husband and the ER staff. False hope was offered and because of the pressures at work I failed to stand up for my precious pets right to a peaceful pass surrounded by his loved ones. After a couple of months of debates and arguments, my husband finally understood. Jed should have been relieved of his pain. If I understand this survey correctly the goal is to find a way to turn regret into a positive path forward. That is where the block is. While we want to adopt/rescue another dog the pain of losing Jed that way prevents me from opening my heart to the joy and love of bringing in a new member of the family. I guess I am skipping love to avoid pain.
Using drugs and not dealing with childhood trauma throughout my 20s. Not going to highschool or completing college .

I regret shutting out my sister 14 years ago, and my inability/unwillingness to admit to and rectify the situation. I know I will regret my stubbornness for the rest of my life.

When I was about 25 I wrote a letter and sent a mixed tape to show called "BuzzKill" on MTV. One of the men from the show, Travis Draft, called me and left a message on my phone. I was too Shy to call him back and always regretted it! Similarly, many years ago I left a little piece of art and a note for the actor Tim Robbins at a bar he played at in Evanston, IL. Later his assistant called me and said two tickets were waiting for us at the venue. It was late, we had been out for a bike ride, and I made the excuse that I was too tired and it was too late. Finally, when I was about 35 a woman hit me with her car while I was riding my bike. I was knocked unconscious. I received a letter from an ambulance chasing lawyer and threw it away, priding myself on not being petty and vindictive. Later I was summonsed to court because the moron who hit me pleaded "not guilty" and I had to appear as a witness. I really regret not suing that cretin! I barely got any money from her insurers.

I regret not spending time with either of my grandmothers when they were elderly, before they died. My father's mother was very kind, warm, amiable- very easy to be with. But when she started ailing at the end of her life, I didn't want to be around her. I seldom called or even wrote to her. My mother's mother was more difficult to like, but as an adult, I have more sympathy for the obstacles she faced. She had significant depression and anxiety, which made her difficult to like. She rotted in a medicaid nursing home in rural Illinois, barely anyone visited (just my mother, I believe twice a month.) It would have meant a lot to her to have more visits.
But they both deserved more love and attention from me. I was in my mid 20's, old enough to know better!

My greatest regret is that in April, 2020, I did not go to see mom in the nursing home when she was dying of covid-19, even though I was offered the opportunity and scarce personal protective equipment.  I was scared of catching and spreading the virus and especially did not want to have to delay by 2 weeks the opportunity to live with my fiance in his safer community, so I asked the nurse if mom would be aware of my presence and felt relieved when told "probably not".

I went with my father to meet with his doctor before surgery for colon cancer.  I asked as many questions as I knew, the doctor drew diagrams and tried to explain, then he told me not to worry my pretty little head about it, my father had lived a long life.   My father was there and lucid.  My father made it through the surgery with flying colors and then in about two weeks the sutures failed and he ended up back in the hospital and died a horrible death, in excruciating pain until his heart gave out.  All because he was malnurished and we didn't know.  Evidently this is something that happens routinely with eldery patients.  The doctor never considered it or checked and I didn't know to ask.  I lost the most important person in my life through ignorance.  He might not have listened to me if  I had known and wanted him to postpone, but we'll never know.
I regret blaming my mother for smoking for over 50 years which led to her lung cancer, and subsequently her death.

For me it's a bit hard to say. For one hand I don't believe so much in the concept of regret. I like to think that every choice I made over the years are in a way responsible for who I'm today and I'm mostly proud of myself. So silly regrets like not learning a third language? Yes, but maybe "regret" is a strong word for that feeling. But in the end, wouldn't call it a regret itself but a wish. A wish to live life. I think although regret is a concept I don't fully "believe", is one that pushes me forward. The fear of regrets is more than a fuel than the regret itself. By the end I know I won't regret. I know that I'll do my best. As this idea, the need to avoid the regret, will keep me in line.

My stoic, stubborn and private older sister, to whom I was very close, had stage 4 colon cancer in her 30s. During her 4 year illness, I allowed a new marriage, new job, new home and complicated births of 2 children to excuse me from more actively supporting her. Nor did she make it easy. I later realized I was her sole confidant during that time, that she had tried to indirectly share her grief at the infidelity of her husband during her illness. In despair and anger, she died without ever sharing a written or spoken word regarding her wishes for her four young children or preparing them in any way. I regret not pushing on the door she needed me to walk through during that time. For those you love, step across, take a breath, allow yourself to see, be a presence, pay the price.

When I married the first time at age 25, naturally I wanted my dad to attend the ceremony. My parents had divorced when I was 12, and it was nasty. I’ll never know why my dad chose not to attend my wedding (my mom’s presence?) and get to know my then-husband, but I was angry about it and didn’t have any contact with my dad for decades. He didn’t reach out to me, either. Flash forward to about 2014, and I was taking my teen daughter to Orlando. I wanted my dad to meet her, so we drove to the Tampa area for a somewhat awkward but ultimately lovely day or two before my daughter and I went to have fun in Orlando and then fly home. My dad and I had several phone conversations after that where we both expressed our regrets for all the time lost, all the years of the silent treatment. He died of a sudden heart attack a couple years ago. I am crying as I write this, because I will always regret not having contacted him during those decades of estrangement. I’ll always regret being an asshole.

I went to an elite UK university, won a scholarship while there and looked set to go on to an academic career. That was my dream. But on the first day of finals I totally lost my nerve, panicked, missed the exams and went AWOL for a couple of days (regret 1). After tracking me down, my parents persuaded me to go back and complete the rest of my exams, which, out of guilt I did and so ended up with a mediocre degree (regret 2) - quite an achievement in the circumstances, I guess, but devastating for an incurable perfectionist like me. If only I'd either had the courage to turn up for the exams on day one and taken my chances or stuck to my decision to drop out at the 11th hour and saved myself further humiliation. But I did neither. I took the coward's path - twice in succession. They say you regret the things you didn't do more than those you did. But my 'sin' was both of commission and omission. After 40yrs, it's a double wound that has never healed. Time, you are not a great healer!

There was a sign on it that said ‘keep out’. After feeding the cat for a while and becoming attached as it learned to trust me (slow process), I decided he needed a nickname of sorts. He became Keep Out from there and we grew to be great friends. He would eventually start coming right to our apartments door for his daily meals. He learned the feeding schedule and always showed up on time. I loved this cat and wanted to make him mine, but my husband and I already had 4 cats of our own. I regret not taking him in or at the very least catching him and taking him to a shelter. My husband and I finally got a house and moved out of state. I regrettably had to leave him behind. I think about him so often and I hope he found a loving and safe home. I miss him terribly.
